column5: Model negative binomal of density against year, with random effect (unknown whether intercept or slope) of location. Each species is modelled seperately

column4: Aim to understand trend and drivers
column5: Correlation between abundance and year. No hierarchical structure. Every species modelled speretately. Never aggregated

column7: No mention or assessment of any autocor aspect

column4: Aim to understand trend and drivers
column5: Models abundance against time and covariates, with a poisson error term. Species random intercept term.
column7: No mention or assessment of any autocor aspect

column4: Aim to understand trend and drivers
column5: Two stage. First a simple log-linear model of abundance againstr year; extracting the beta coeffieicnt. These are then modelled in a LMM with species and location as random intercepts (which are functionally slopes)
column7: No mention or assessment of any autocor aspect

column5: Two stage. First stage uses TRIM (a log linear model of abundance in a given site in a given year). Second stage is a lmm of beta coefficient with covariates and species/site random effects. Ignore spatial structure within countires
column7: Accounts for temporal autocorrelation in the intercept TRIM model apparently. Cant find anything that shows this

column5: Two stage. Extracted national bird abundance trends from another study (Referenced as Birdlife 2015 but no functioning link; most likely refers to the PECMBS TRIM indicies). Then fits bird abundance trends with a gamm containing lat and long (so some recognition of spatial sturcture); but its unclear how many knots were used etc (or whhether this was just just linear). Also contained species and family random effects, which the study states captures phylogenetic signal, but never tested this
column7: States that latitude and longitdue covariates, and taxonomic ranom effects, are sufficient at capturing spatial and phylogwnetic signal

column4: Aim to understand trend and drivers
column5: Two stage. First extracting beta coefficient as a fisher z effect size. Then used meta regression with trend as the response and spatial and taxonomic random effects
column7: Tested for spatial and phylogenetic signal and found no effect

column5: Abundance of assemblage is derived, meaning all species abundances are combined. Study accounts for temporal autocorrelation within total abundanbce of assemblage with an AR1 GLS. Ignores phylogentic sturcture as a consequence of simply adding abundances of all species. Spatial structure is ignored as medians are reported in a boxplot i.e. no model derived average
column6: Two: Total over community, then median aggregated
column7: Accounts for temporal autocorrelation. Spatial and phylogentic ignored

column4: Aim to understand trend and drivers
column5: Two stage. Species population trend derived by modelling abundance as product of covariates 'year' and 'site'. AR1 within time series is captured. This model is equivalent to an AR1. In a second stage of the analysis, phylogenetic singnal in species trends in captued with a gls.
column7: Accounts for temporal autocorrelation. Then sperately phylogentic correlation

column4: Aim to understand trend and drivers
column5: Two stage. Abundances summed across different locations to derive species toal abundance for each year. Pearson correlation between log total abundance and year. Species trends never aggregated.
column6: Two: Total over space, then poll counted
column7: No mention or assessment of any autocor aspect

column4: Aim to understand trend and drivers
column5: Two stage. Abundances summed across different locations to derive species toal abundance for each year. Regression between total abundance and year. Species trends aggregated into covariate groups whilst contorlling for phylogeny
column6: Two: Total over space, then slope
column7: Accounts for phylogeny only

column4: Aim to understand trend and drivers
column5: Uses TRIM to derive species trends and then uses MSI to join species trends
column7: Accounts for temporal autocorrelation in the intercept TRIM model apparently. Cant find anything that shows this

column4: Aim to understand trend and drivers
column5: Uses a dynamic N-mix, from Dali and Madsen, to estimate trends for each species whilst accounting for imperefect detection. Only derives species trends. Not assemblage or community trends
column7: Accounts for temporal autocorrelation

column5: Uses TRIM to derive species trends
column6: Two: population trend, then poll counted
column7: Accounts for temporal autocorrelation

column5: Derives growth rate per population, and averages this across all species and locations to derive mean growth rate. Also recoducts analysis per species, to develop species specific estimates of change
column6: Mixed: Population trends then averaging, then poll count
column7: No mention or assessment of any autocor aspect

column4: Aim to understand trend and drivers
column5: Uses TRIM to derive species trends. Then poll counts somewhat to report on the entire assemblage
column6: Two: population trend, then poll counted
column7: Accounts for temporal autocorrelation

column5: Model log abundance as a product of year, with location random intercept and slope. Account for AR1 in sites. No species or taxonomic random effects
column7: Accounts for temporal autocorrelation

column5: Model log abundance against scaled year accounting for AR1. Then averages across populations to derive global median (tests with 1-sample T).
column7: Accounts for temporal autocorrelation

column4: Aim to understand trend and drivers

column7: Accounts for temporal autocorrelation in time series, and phylogenitc correlationa scross

column4: Aim to understand trend and drivers

column5: Derive speices trends a couple of ways, but all with the same core principle, where abundance is a product of year (countinuos), site and season i.e. the random intercept model. They checked for temporal autoco, but ignore spatial. Authors then aggregate trends with a pgls meta regression
column6: Two: Random intercept, then random slope
column7: Tests for temporal autocor. Accounts for phylo. Ignores spatial

column5: Abundance against year, with cycling/periodicity removed. No mention of random effects for space or species. All species totaled into one 'grassjoppers;
